That is why it is again simply a matter of great disappointment to those in rural areas to hear Mr Beazley say, when accompanying the Labor Party's current spokesperson Ms Kernot, `Well, the purpose of coming to visit Central Queensland is basically Cheryl.' In other words, he was not up there interested in finding out what was going on. He was not interested in listening or helping. He was simply there going through the political motions. Of course, Cheryl Kernot herself, when explaining why she had not managed to get to Rockhampton in a very long time, said, `I've got to balance the responsibility of talking to regional communities with looking after a marginal seat.' That is the level of commitment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston in his capacity as minister representing the foreign minister. Does the minister recall the words of the recent military commander in Dili, Colonel Suratman, on the 30 May Sunday program when he said:

question.para: If the pro-independents do win, it won't just be the Government of Indonesia that has to deal with what follows. The UN and Australia are also going to have to solve the problem. And well if this does happen then there'll be no winners, everything is going to be destroyed. East Timor won't exist as it does now. It'll be much worse than 23 years ago.
How does the government regard this statement and the many similar threats by pro-integrationist militia leaders?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, we are certainly conscious of the fact that there are elements in the Indonesian military who were not supportive of the process, but there were, of course, those at the highest level, including General Wiranto and of course President Habibie, who did acknowledge that this was a very sensible step forward. It is, of course, easy with hindsight to say that one should have anticipated the reaction to the overwhelming vote in support of independence, but I do not think anyone seriously expected anything like the magnitude of the violence that has occurred since that time. Certainly the information available to the government—much of it conflicting—was the basis on which we went forward with that process.

answer.para: We were always concerned that there was a serious risk of violence, but certainly we did not anticipate the level which ultimately occurred. There are, as I say, some who have talked in those terms; there are others who have not. It is a very difficult judgement to make about what you reasonably expect, but certainly we were prepared to take the assurances provided by those at the highest levels that they would facilitate the act of self-determination and allow for the processes to proceed in the proper manner. Certainly it was always understood that there might be a role for Australia and the United Nations, and the speed with which that process has been put in place in recent times is testimony to the fact that we were certainly preparing ourselves for some eventuality of that sort.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government accept that the pro-integrationist militias in East Timor have not only included a significant number of Indonesian military personnel but are in fact being effectively controlled by the TNI?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not know that anyone could give you a precise answer to that question, suffice to say that the rest of the world, including the President of the United States, takes the view that the TNI, the Indonesian military, were in a position to have exercised a much greater degree of discipline than they did. From what we saw on our own televisions screens it was apparent that, even though they were sent into Dili after the event, they were basically condoning what was occurring. The extent to which people might have been militias by day and army by night will never be precisely determined, but certainly the military should now be held responsible for exercising the authority that is clearly vested in them to control the militia as much as possible. Certainly we are very concerned that they did not and that is the basis upon which subsequent events have been put in place.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. In February 1998 the Prime Minister committed the government to ensuring that Australia has a Federal Police agency which is second to none in the world. Will the minister advise the Senate of developments since the Prime Minister made that undertaking?

—I thank Senator Payne for the question. Today, with my colleague the Minister for Finance and Administration, I have announced that the government has decided to make available funding of up to a further $155 million over the next three years to the Australian Federal Police for its staffing and resource upgrade program. This reaffirms our commitment to the development of the Australian Federal Police as the Commonwealth's major instrument for law enforcement.

answer.para: The financial injection will enable the Federal Police Modernisation Program to continue, including the development of conditions of service for the Federal Police staff to ensure that the Federal Police attracts and retains the highest calibre of law enforcement professionals. The Federal Police has been implementing a $115 million reform program set in place by the Prime Minister and me last year. That provided an initial $65 million over three years to increase staffing levels and enable the Federal Police to become a law enforcement agency second to none. Last year the Federal Police commenced its first major recruiting in years, moving to a staffing level of 2,800. The achievements of the Federal Police since commencing the 1998 reform program have been nothing short of remarkable. Consistent with the earlier financial reforms, the injection of this new funding will be released progressively to the Federal Police. The Federal Police monitoring committee will oversight the release in stages, one of which will involve the ratification by the AIRC of a new certified agreement which is presently being negotiated.

It gives me great pleasure to record this significant decision on the eve of the Federal Police's 20th anniversary of its formation in October 1979. The government is confident of the AFP being able to meet the range of law enforcement challenges in the 21st century, including illicit drugs, organised crime including sex slavery and people smuggling, corruption and money laundering. The Australian Federal Police is currently concluding negotiations on a package of service conditions proposed in this new certified agreement. I understand that during this week details of the negotiations will be settled and broadcast to all AFP personnel.

Law enforcement personnel in the Federal Police are highly regarded and well qualified for their very specialised roles. Of course regrettably these levels of qualifications and skills, coupled with the professional work carried out by the Federal Police, make it not surprising that some Federal Police personnel are being poached on a fairly regular basis but we should be proud of the skills and training that we provide them with to make them so poachable. Equally, with proper remuneration packaging, the Australian Federal Police expects a reduction in the number of personnel leaving as a consequence of poaching offers. Therefore it seems appropriate that the Federal Police seek to progress moving high valued AFP personnel onto proper professional remuneration packaging.

I want to commend the work of all AFP personnel and in particular take this opportunity to recognise the roles of those recently returned from East Timor. The Federal Police deployed 50 members to East Timor as part of UNAMET. As you know, Madam Deputy President, the contingent was evacuated completely last week. From my own observations in Darwin last week welcoming the Federal Police home, they have displayed considerable professionalism and courage during their time. They served UNAMET with absolute distinction and UNAMET was largely responsible for the successful completion of that historic ballot and the return of the ballot boxes. The conduct of the Federal Police under dangerous conditions has been a credit to the professionalism of the Federal Police and a recognition of Australia's dedication to the United Nations.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston in his role as acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister confirm that up to 6,500 US military personnel will be in Australia over coming weeks to participate in exercise Crocodile 99? On what date did the government first formally seek United States participation in the International Force for East Timor? Did the government at any time seek the commitment of US combat troops? If so, when and how many?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not in a position to provide the Senate with the details that Senator Faulkner has sought. But certainly the government does welcome the cooperation of the United States and their willingness to provide a force that will give not only logisti cal support but also in many respects long haul communications and equipment facilities. Some 200 military personnel have already been pledged in support of the INTERFET mission. We certainly value very much the commitment of the United States government to provide other ongoing intelligence assistance. I will see what more I can obtain by way of additional information, but I am not sure that some of the more detailed aspects of that question, including what might presumably have been private discussions between governments, are appropriate matters for disclosure.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister has indicated that he will seek further advice. In relation to the detailed questions that I have asked the minister, I would appreciate him seeking urgent advice on those matters and reporting back to the Senate as a matter of urgency.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I will do whatever can be done and should be done.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the taxation statistics published by the tax office which show a large and growing tax avoidance opportunity through small private companies. Is the minister aware that 60 per cent of private companies, with a total income of some $150 billion, do not pay any income tax? Is the minister aware that this proportion has risen from 28 per cent of all companies in 1991 to 38.5 per cent of total private company income last year? Can the minister categorically state that the government takes the clearly growing issue of tax avoidance through incorporation seriously and that before any move is made to increase the gap between the top marginal tax rate and the company tax rate the government will move to close those loopholes?

—I thank Senator Murray for that question. Senator Murray, I think the government record shows that this government takes extremely strong action in relation to people who seek to avoid their taxes. This government does not like tax bludgers and this government has taken a wide range of measures to ensure proper compliance with the tax law and to close the very wide range of loopholes that were left to us by the previous government. Let me list some of the issues which we have tackled in our term in office.

answer.para: We have introduced measures in this chamber to address the issue of dividends disguised as private company loans. I think many senators will recall that there was a bill passed through this chamber on that issue. We have moved on the misuse of charitable trusts to distribute funds overseas. There was a very important debate in this chamber on trust losses. It would be recalled that the Labor Party was in government for 13 years and failed to move effectively to deal with the issue of trust losses. We have moved in other areas such as franking credit trading and dividend streaming. Again, they have been other important measures brought forward by this government. There has been, and I think members of the Labor Party would be particularly aware of this, abuse of the R&D syndication.

talk.start.para: —Like those battlers in Brighton.

—Well, the Labor Party developed an extraordinary view on that particular issue. That was quite clear. There was widespread abuse in this area, Senator Conroy, and we failed to get proper support from the Labor Party on this very important issue to close that loophole. This government has a very strong record on tackling tax avoidance. It is a record that we are proud of, but it is a record which will always require the most careful scrutiny to make sure that, as new schemes are developed, the government, where appropriate, can move to close those schemes down. Let me make it clear and give Senator Murray this assurance: this government does not like tax bludgers, and we have taken very strong action in that area.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for your reply, but my question is really prospective rather than retrospective. I want to know what else you are going to do. Does the minister agree that the government has a moral duty to do all it can to close tax loopholes to provide an adequate revenue base to fund increased defence obligations before proceeding to cut health, education and social spending, as the Treasurer indicated he might do last week? Shouldn't we make tax avoiders pay their fair share before asking the sick, the young, the aged and the unemployed to pay for defence through more spending cuts?

—Of course the government believes that tax avoiders must pay their fair share. That is why, Senator Murray, I listed a wide range of measures. It certainly was not a complete list of the action that this government has taken to close down loopholes. In relation to future plans of the government, it would not be appropriate for me to make comment on that in this chamber, but I can assure Senator Murray and the wider community that this government will always move to ensure that people pay their fair share of tax. People have a duty to pay their fair share of tax. This government, unlike the previous government, has cracked down very seriously and savagely on tax avoidance.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor: International Commission of Inquiry

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the United Nations Human Rights Commissioner Mary Robinson's proposal for an international commission of inquiry into East Timor atrocities. Can the minister assure the Senate that the government will lend every support to the proposed commission of inquiry including the provision of relevant information held by Australian intelligence concerning the Indonesian military, police and militias and their chain of command?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am aware of Commissioner Mary Robinson's outspoken concern on this matter, particularly not only the prospect of a United Nations commission of inquiry but even the possibility of the establishment of a war crimes tribunal. In the current circumstances, the government takes the view that these are matters that are best left until a later point in time. That is not to say that they are not matters of very considerable importance but, in the scheme of things, there are other matters that are more urgent. We should not be seen to condone any of the action that has occurred on the one hand, nor should we be seen to take steps that might be seen by some of those who are already opposed to us or those who take a negative view of Australia as simply a basis for suggesting that we are further seeking to antagonise Indonesia.

answer.para: Our concern of course has been very forcibly expressed at the highest levels, but we are anxious to ensure that we have the best possible working relationship with that country. We have taken steps to suspend joint exercises and training activities. We will be ready to take other action if that is necessary. But I simply say that those calls are ones that need some careful consideration. The government will take those matters on board. To the extent that we might ultimately provide intelligence information, I would have thought that that was a very sensitive issue that would require very careful consideration.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Firstly, what recognition and facilitation is being given to Xanana Gusmao and the CNRT, the government in exile, so that they can begin the long and difficult work of representing the people of East Timor from Darwin? Secondly, can the government say that all military aid, direct or indirect of any variety whatsoever, has been stopped between Australia and Indonesia?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —As far as Xanana Gusmao's position in Darwin is concerned, he left Jakarta and arrived in Australia on 19 September. It is the government's understanding that he plans to consult with members of the East Timorese community in Darwin. There have been suggestions by Mr Carrascalao that he might indeed seek to operate a type of government in exile from Darwin, but the government is not aware of that firm proposal or intention. Certainly, his mere presence in Darwin does not constitute a government in exile. He will obviously play a key role in the UNAMET process and arrangements to be established by the UN under the tripartite agreement for East Timor's transition to independence.

answer.para: It is perfectly understandable that he would wish to return to East Timor as soon as possible. His security remains a critical issue not only for himself but also for all those others who are looking to him for guidance and leadership. The government has done its best to ensure that he is fully apprised of the difficulties that might be faced if he were to return, at least in the short term. At the present time, while the multinational force is in the process of re-establishing order and taking whatever action is necessary, it may well be a more prudent course to wait and see how things settle down. The government would anticipate that the militia will be much less involved than they have been in recent times. It may mean that it will be possible for him to return later with a greater confidence in his long-term security than if he were to contemplate going there in the very near future.

As far as the latter part of Senator Brown's question is concerned, my understanding is that whilst we have suspended joint exercises and training programs, and we have certainly suspended exercises with Kopassus, we have not at this point in time terminated all military agreements with Indonesia. We remain willing to provide whatever humanitarian assistance might be required.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question following that second answer. Can the minister give the Senate an assurance that while Australian personnel are part of the UN peacekeeping force in East Timor there will be absolutely no military aid of any sort to the military authorities in Indonesia? Can the minister explicitly say what is meant by `humanitarian aid' and give the Senate an assurance that that which is other than what he calls `humanitarian aid'—the exchange of money or support, direct or indirect, of any sort—will not be going to the Indonesian military from this country?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of any intention or desire on the part of the Austral ian government to provide any form of military assistance to the government of Indonesia at this time. All of our efforts are concentrated in East Timor, where we expect there will be a reduction in the level of Indonesian military personnel. Senator Brown seems to be suggesting that the term `humanitarian aid' can cover a multitude of sins and be a disguised method of providing money and other assistance in kind. It was certainly not in that context that I used the term. I think we all understand what is properly meant by `humanitarian aid'. It is usually emergency relief and assistance to individuals and families—people—rather than infrastructure and other support.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Howard government share the views of the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives and the National Party member Mr Garry Nehl when he praised Chinese rule in Tibet? For instance, does the government agree that the current Chinese rule is better for the Tibetan people than any alternative? Does the Howard government agree with Mr Nehl's view that the only role the Chinese army plays in Tibet is to protect the borders and that New South Wales police booze buses are more threatening than the Chinese army in Tibet?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I have not seen Mr Nehl's comments, but I am aware that he has expressed—
—Everyone else has! What've you been doing? Do your job!

—I am saying that I have not studied them. I am aware of the fact that he has made some comments, and I have seen press reports, but I have not read the comments. He has expressed a personal view—which, of course, he is free to do—but the government's position has been consistent and clear. Tibet has made significant economic progress over the last few years, but that progress by no means lessens our concern about continuing reports of human rights abuse in Tibet. The government takes very seriously any continuing allegations of that nature, and the bilateral human rights dialogue enables us to register our views at a very senior level with China. Tibet was an important item on the agenda of this year's dialogue held in China from 16 to 20 August. As well as broader issues like arbitrary detentions in China, our delegation registered with key agencies specific concerns about religious freedom and cultural identity in Tibet. We also encouraged substantial dialogue with the Dalai Lama. Our delegation impressed on Chinese authorities the high level of Australian community interest in Tibet.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that Mr Nehl has admitted that he did not speak to any Tibetan people on his visit and that he only saw what his Chinese hosts wanted him to see, does the government agree that it would be preferable for an Australian parliamentarian on a human rights visit to actually insist on speaking directly to the Tibetan people? Will the government take Mr Nehl's report on Tibet seriously or will it be filed under `tourist snow job'?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I would have thought Senator Schacht would be the last one to give lectures on people who regard themselves as human rights experts grandstanding in front of television cameras and making statements from around the world for domestic consumption. As I have indicated, Mr Nehl is entitled, indeed probably obliged, to provide reports to the parliament about visits that are undertaken in an official capacity. We would all have our own views. It is not the role of the government to tell people what they ought to see, whom they ought to visit and what views they ought to form. I would have thought even if we tried to do that with someone like Senator Schacht, he would probably misunderstand most of it and then read from the script he had prepared before he left home.
—Settle down!
—I will take Senator Conroy's advice.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. Will the minister outline the government's neutral public education program for the coming referendum? What is the purpose of this program? Have the ads been designed to ensure all Australians have an understanding of the issues?

—Thank you, Senator Parer, for that very important question. The Constitutional Convention last year said that there should be a neutral education campaign, and we took that advice on board and committed ourselves, in the last election, to run just that. In this campaign, which started yesterday, we are informing Australians about the process of the referendum and about the fact that you need a double majority, or a majority of voters in a majority of states. We are informing voters about the current system of government in this country, and we are informing Australians about the question that will be put to them on 6 November.

answer.para: In getting this together, we took the advice of an expert panel which was chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen. In fact, we also had Professor Geoffrey Blainey, Dr John Hirst, Dr Colin Howard and Professor Cheryl Saunders. It is well known that these are eminent Australians—a diverse group, indeed—and Australians who have different views. I take this opportunity on behalf of the government to thank them for their contribution in helping the government settle this pamphlet. It is noted on the pamphlet—there will be 12 million distributed across the country—that this expert panel helped the government. The pamphlet will form the basis of the neutral education campaign. Of course, we are running TV, radio and print advertisements but the pamphlet is the basis of our campaign.

We are also informing Australians as to not only the question on the republic but also the question on the preamble, and it is entirely appropriate that we do that. But of course you still have criticism, and I see that the Leader of the Opposition has criticised this advertising as being biased. In fact, he said that the $9.5 million could be better spent on the troops in East Timor. He did not say that under him defence expenditure fell from 2.6 per cent of the GDP to 2.1 per cent. He also did not take note of the government polling which showed that some 65 to 92 per cent of Australians surveyed in that poll wanted more information about the forthcoming referendum. That is what the Leader of the Opposition is failing to realise. Forty-three per cent of those polled thought the President would be directly elected by the people of Australia, and we know that is not true.

We are fixing that with this pamphlet and with the TV ads. We are advising the people of Australia that there is more information available. Do not just take my word for it; look at what Graham Richardson said this morning on 2GB. He said the ads were pretty fair, and I am sure he is not a monarchist or an ACM supporter. This campaign is devoted to getting information out into the community and to helping Australians make an informed decision of 6 November. Naturally, there will be some people who will think it is biased one way or another—you will always get that—but I reject totally what the Leader of the Opposition has said in relation to these ads. He is obviously ignoring the polling that took place which showed that people are crying out for more information. To those people who think that our campaign is biased, I would advise them to do themselves a favour and read this pamphlet carefully, and they will see just how on the mark it is.

talk.start.para: —Where can I get a copy?
—Senator Kemp has asked where he can get a copy. He just has to call my office.

—My question is to Senator Alston, representing the Prime Minister. In the view of the Howard government, what impact did the punishing industrial relations policies of the Kennett government have on the devastating verdict of the Victorian people last Saturday? What about the headlong privatisation of essential government services, the withdrawal of many services from regional and rural communities and the diversion of significant public funding into the subsidisation of pet projects like car races and casinos? From Victoria, what can the Howard government learn about the inevitable result of its own forays into a `security guard and dogs' approach to industrial relations, its insistence on selling off government services no matter the social cost and its short-sighted withdrawal of Commonwealth services from regional areas?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Straight out of central ACTU casting—a classic example of the agenda; the script was handed out on Saturday night. I had to sit through a fair bit of this sort of nonsense—no-one believed it for a moment. One of the things arising out of that state election—and this is very important because we are all willing to learn from near death experiences—and it is something I would have thought the Federal Labor Party would be interested in doing, was the achievement of a much broader spread of representation from the community, particularly if you aspire to represent rural seats where there are very serious issues. I do not for a moment underestimate the problems that are being faced in rural and remote Victoria. That is why we established the social bonus programs, that is why we established the Networking the Nation Program, and that is why the Labor Party hated every bit of it. What is the lesson you learn from a party dominated by the trade union movement? What you learn is that out of the 11 seats that the ALP claims to have won, five would be represented by people whose most recent occupation has been as an ALP staffer, three are union officials and organisers, one is a teacher and one is a welfare worker. The other one is merely part of a political dynasty—Mr Tresize.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister will resume his seat until we have silence in the chamber. I will have order, from both sides.

—It ought to be clear that there is a significant level of concern in rural Australia and indeed rural Victoria about a whole range of things. There is very great concern about the fact that the Labor Party simply ran around being negative and did not offer them much. Of course, we know at the federal level that Senator Conroy, because he is a regular briefer and leaker to the Melbourne Age , was out there telling them that he and Stephen Smith and Shayne Murphy and Nick Sherry had all violently opposed what the leader had been doing in terms of infrastructure and regional community activities. He made it clear that they no longer had any faith in Mr Beazley's ability to retain the Labor vote in rural areas.

answer.para: There is a lot to be learnt because, quite clearly, if the best Cheryl Kernot can do is to say, `I'd like to get out there more than once every 12 months but I am looking after a marginal seat,' then you have a long way to go. If you are serious about it, come up with some decent policies. Do not just pretend that somehow you can set up a very fast train all around Victoria into Tullamarine for $20 million when the true cost is something in excess of $200 million. When we look seriously at what Labor had to offer, we find there was very little indeed. I think people, particularly outside the metropolitan areas, are entitled to receive a lot more than the ACTU is prepared to offer people like Senator Collins. You ought to ask the ACTU for some serious policy advice. They should use some of those union dues to set up some decent research outfits and to find out what is really happening in these places so that you do not just trot out all the usual ideological pap.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether the minister can think of anything other than parroting about the ACTU. Can this watershed in Victorian politics also be put down to the government's outright arrogance and refusal to be accountable for any action, as suggested in today's Financial Review ? And speaking of arrogance, has the minister, with his interest in Internet surfing, looked at the Internet site Jeff.com today? Is he aware that the site has been frozen? Should the Liberal Party rename the site Jeff.full stop? And has the minister sent in his own CV to be the next premier?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I would have thought that those who had seen the billboards advertising Jeff.com would have appreciated that it was for the purpose of the upcoming election. So it is not altogether surprising that, after the election, the site does not have quite the same relevance and resonance that it might have had in the lead-up period. Everyone will have their views and reasons why the result went the way it did. There will be those who will be pushing ideological barrows like Senator Collins.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am very interested to see the degrees of swings. They were about three times greater in rural areas than they were in metropolitan areas. So all this business of somehow suggesting that it was all due to arrogance and to a dislike of the premier is clearly not the case, otherwise we would have expected a uniform swing across the state. There were a lot of important factors at work in rural Australia. If you seriously want to tackle them, you should start doing some policy work instead. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Airspace Trial

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Ian Macdonald. Is the government concerned that it is now over nine months since the class G airspace trial was terminated but the report of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has not been released? Is the minister aware that the draft report into the class G airspace trial finds that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority mismanaged the trial to a degree that jeopardised public safety, and that BASI has found there is `a systematic weakness in the leadership and management of CASA, which had a direct bearing on aviation safety'? Minister, when will the BASI report be released?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Woodley's question does show the organisation that the government has in place regarding air service matters, and obviously BASI has looked very closely into the issue.
—Where is the BASI report? That is the question.
—Senator Mackay, if you want to ask a question, please get up and ask me something on your portfolio. I do not think I have had a question from you in recent months.
—Order! Can I have some order please. Senator Macdonald, I would appreciate it if you would address the chair and not react to interjections.

—I do get provoked by interjections from Senator Mackay, who is supposed to be shadowing me and who never asks a question relative to the portfolio. As I was saying, the government has aviation matters well in hand. The fact that BASI is inquiring into these issues shows that we have an interest in it. Senator Woodley asked me when the report will be released. I will refer that question to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, and give Senator Woodley a response. But when BASI indicates in its investigations that there are problems, as Senator Woodley has indicated, the government takes the issue very seriously and it is obviously something that Mr Anderson, as transport minister, will be following through. As soon as I can, I will get back to Senator Woodley on the specific answers to his questions.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, and particularly for the assurance that the government will take the report seriously. Minister, I am afraid that the report may be an indictment on the authority responsible for aviation safety and I wonder, when you are asking the minister, whether you might ask him to ensure that the final BASI report is not a watered-down version of the draft.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I take some umbrage from even a suggestion that reports might be watered down. BASI is a very responsible organisation and makes its own reports. As I have indicated, the government treats with very great seriousness any matters that BASI might raise. Senator Woodley, I will not pass on that last bit to Mr Anderson or to BASI because I consider it inappropri ate, but I will certainly get back to you on the substantial question.

—My question is directed to Senator Ellison, the Special Minister of State. Minister, is it true that the independent committee, chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen, to approve the government's neutral public education and information campaign for the republic referendum was not given the opportunity to meet to consider the final script for the television advertisements before those advertisements were shot? Isn't it true that the members of the committee were only individually sent copies of the final scripts and asked to comment just before the advertisements were shot?

—Can I say at the outset that the committee that I referred to earlier was an advisory committee, and the approval for the advertisements which went out is governed by the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, which I chair. On that committee you have, in this case, the Attorney-General, Mr Georgiou and a representative of the Prime Minister's office. The process adopted for these advertisements was no different from that adopted for any other advertisement conducted in relation to a government program or campaign. As I said earlier, the pamphlet which I have here forms the basis of the neutral education campaign. The print ads and the television advertisements were drawn from this pamphlet. The television advertisements are complementary to this pamphlet. What you have on the television advertisements is information about the referendum—the fact that there are two choices and the fact that you can get more information and the number to call. You cannot put all the detail in relation—

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With respect, I asked a follow-up question to a dorothy dix question that Senator Ellison received earlier in question time today. I asked whether the independent committee chaired by Sir Ninian Stephen was given an opportunity to meet to consider the final script and whether in fact members of the committee were only individually sent copies of final scripts and asked to comment just before the advertisements were shot. That is the question, Madam Deputy President, and I would ask you if you could direct Senator Ellison to answer this important question.

—Madam Deputy President, as I said, this is an advisory committee. It was never intended that final approval for the advertisement would be given by the committee—in fact, the approval for such advertisements comes from the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications—therefore, Senator Faulkner's question entirely misses the point. It entirely misses the point because the process was that the referendum task force settled the wording of the pamphlet and other advertisements and took advice from this advisory committee in relation to the pamphlet and print ads, but the actual style of the advertisement was settled by the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications. It was not the role of this committee to determine the final form of this advertisement; it was not its role at all. That was left to the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, which determines the style and the manner of television and radio advertising and other forms of advertising in relation to government programs. So that was entirely in accordance with what we said we would be doing. Senator Faulkner's question entirely misses the point.

answer.para: The fact remains that the pamphlet—there will be 12 million of these pamphlets distributed around Australia—forms the basis of our information campaign. As acknowledged on that pamphlet, it has been prepared and issued by the Commonwealth government. An expert panel consisting of Sir Ninian Stephen, chairman, Professor Geoffrey Blainey, Professor Cheryl Saunders, Dr John Hirst and Dr Colin Howard reviewed the content to ensure it was fair and accurate. That is the sum total of it. The opposition might well try to speculate or beat up the fact that there is something untoward here. There is nothing untoward. The process has been open and transparent, and these advertisements are fair. I refer again to Graham Richardson on 2GB. He said the ads were pretty fair—and I think he is an avowed republican, if I remember correctly.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister either could not or would not answer the questions I asked of him. But, given that the minister mentioned the role of the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, which he chairs, the involvement of Mr Georgiou and the involvement of a representative of the Prime Minister's office, I ask if the decisions in relation to these particular advertisements were made in a telephone hook-up of the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, whether any others were involved in the telephone hook-up and, if so, who they were? And perhaps the minister can put our minds at rest and assure us that Senator Minchin was not involved.

—Madam Deputy President, I am trying to think what I had for breakfast that day. I might just tell Senator Faulkner that too. The normal processes were followed in relation to the determination of these advertisements. I might just remind Senator Faulkner again that there was a referendum task force, comprising the Attorney-General and me, which settled the wording.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is this: the minister has tried to defend the government's actions here by highlighting the role of the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications. I asked the nature of the meeting—whether it was a hook-up—and I asked who was on it and whether Senator Minchin was involved in the hook-up. I think we are entitled to an answer to those important questions when this minister is trying to defend the processes of the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Ellison is answering the question as he sees fit. If his answer does not fit what you wish him to say, you can have another question later on.

—Senator Faulkner asked whether Senator Minchin was involved in the processes of the MCGC, and he was not. That is it. He was not involved in those deliberations. It is just another beat-up. Senator Faulkner is just beating it up again. These ads were focused tested, they were found to be neutral and they get the information across.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Can the minister explain how yesterday's announcement of the removal of $18 million in nuisance tariffs will assist Australian consumers and manufacturers?

—I thank Senator Tchen for his question. Can I assure the Senate that I am much more interested in reducing the costs to industry in this country than I am in advertising campaigns. Therefore, I was very pleased to announce yesterday that the government is getting rid of $18 million in costs imposed on industry and consumers in the form of nuisance tariffs. Given that the major justification for tariffs in this country is that we should protect Australian industry or assist industry, it is obviously nonsensical to have tariffs on goods that are imported for which there is absolutely no domestic production or competition. These are so-called `nuisance tariffs' and are imposed on products as diverse as ballpoint pen refills, video games, squash racquets, brewery machinery, instant print film, overhead travelling cranes, et cetera.

answer.para: None of these are made in Australia, but all of them are subject to a tariff of between three and five per cent. They are not assisting Australian industry at all. All they are doing is raising the price of these goods to Australian consumers; and they are raising the price of products when they are used as inputs by Australian manufacturers. The importers who bring these products in have to put up with all of the red tape involved in paying the tariffs on these products. As Bert Kelly used to remind us, at the end of the day all tariffs are taxes on Australians, and these nuisance tariffs certainly fit that description. They are nothing more than a sales tax on these products and a tax on Australians.

We initiated a review last year of these nuisance tariffs. About 1,000 tariff classifications were subject to the review. We consulted with industry over a 12-month period and, as a result of that process, identified some 400 tariffs which are not assisting any domestic production whatsoever. So I was very pleased to announce that from 1 November this year these 400 tariffs will be completely abolished, thus removing some $18 million in costs to Australian consumers and industry.

This is part of our overall approach to tariff reform and trade liberalisation. We are examining, as you know, as a result of a Productivity Commission reference, all of our remaining tariffs, with a particular focus on the remaining some 900 nuisance tariffs that are still on products imported into Australia and which are costing consumers and industry some hundreds of millions of dollars. Of course, we will be consulting carefully with industry in this. That review will take about nine months and does fulfil our commitments under APEC to review all of our general tariffs by the end of next year.

I think this is a very important announcement in terms of the WTO meetings to be held in Seattle later this year. It does underline this government's commitment to trade liberalisation, our very good credentials internationally on the issue of trade liberalisation and, of course, our credentials and our commitment to reducing costs for Australian consumers and Australian industry.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Madam Deputy President, I would like to ask a question of Senator Newman. I just ask her if she can, further to the promise she made in the last week of sitting, provide information about the child- care statistics. I wonder if the minister has got those and whether she is able to provide them for us.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —No, I do not have them with me. I will check what has happened.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Collins today, relating to the recent Victorian state election.

One would have thought we would have heard more today from Senator Alston, a former divisional president of the Victorian Liberals and a former campaign director in the last election for Victoria, about the lessons to be learned from Victoria. But it was all too apparent that the message has not been understood by this government. A similar pattern was displayed after the last federal election. I think it appropriate, given that the election in Victoria has yet to conclude, that we understand precisely what this government has taken away from the results that have been dished out to them on Saturday by the people of Victoria.

It is quite apparent that Victoria Inc., as administered by Mr Kennett, is no longer operating. Yet you would not know that from listening to Senator Alston today. Mr Kennett's vision of politics has been routed. Yet, of course, Mr Jeffrey Glib Kennett continues on as if nothing has changed and, if given the opportunity—

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Carr should use Mr Kennett's proper title.
—I suggest that you withdraw the word `glib'.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I was just wondering if Senator Carr would withdraw that and also give us a list of the margins and the swings in the seats.

—I withdraw anything you have asked me to, Mr Acting Deputy Presi dent. It has been demonstrated to us yet again that Mr Jeffrey.com is very glib in his response to the election results of last Saturday. Mr Kennett's humiliation has, of course, demonstrated to this entire country that the Liberal version of politics has got to change. If this government is to survive, then it has to understand that it, too, is responsible for what has been happening in Victoria.

speech.para: What we have seen in Victoria is that the Victorian people have handed out a humiliation to the Liberal government, and particularly to their allies, the National Party. I must take some pleasure regarding Senator McGauran—there he is, just leaving. One would have thought that we would have heard something from Senator McGauran; that we would have heard Senator McGauran's response to Mr Glib Kennett. One would have thought that we would heard something about the way in which this government has been exposed, because the Victorian people have clearly rejected the Liberal version of the secret state. They have clearly rejected the notion that the Liberal governments should withdraw from community activity, should withdraw from the provision of services. They have, of course, rejected the Liberal government's contempt towards people.

The Liberal governments, be they Victorian or be they national, have demonstrated again and again an ideological obsession with undermining and destroying the social fabric of this country. They take the attitude that economic reform has to be pursued at all costs, irrespective of the consequences to the lives of ordinary people. Liberal governments have sought to impose upon the people of this country their vision of what is good for the country without consultation with the people of this country and without any attempt to ameliorate the horrendous effects that so-called economic reform is having upon the lives of ordinary people. This is the supreme arrogance of Liberal governments. It is an arrogance based upon the contention that only they know what is good for this country.

What we have seen is the failure of the National Party to represent its constituency within Victoria, just as we have seen the failure of the National Party within the federal government to represent its constituency. The ultimate expression of this is when the Liberals in Victoria under Jeff Kennett apply the gag to their members of parliament, to their ministers and to all political representatives so that there can be no debate. There can be no engagement with the people of Victoria in relation to the consequences and the costs of the social policies that their government has pursued.

There are further lessons. One would have thought we would have heard from Senator Alston, the former campaign director in Victoria, as to what the costs are to Victoria of the federal government's policies. What are the costs to schools, the costs to TAFE colleges and the costs to universities? Think for a moment about the implications for a university in Ballarat of the shocking policies that are being pursued by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, another Victorian in this government. What effects are those policies having on the people of Victoria? In telecommunications we have seen a similar range of problems. In relation to industrial relations there have been attacks upon ordinary people and their standards of living. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Here we have the Labor Party again trying to pour out successes in order to hide their failures at the federal level. One of the lessons people on the other side ought to learn is that maybe if they focused on what they were supposed to be doing at a federal level rather than crying out about what happened in Victoria, they may actually be better off.

speech.para: Let us look back at what Labor left us after 13 years of government. They ran out of policies, they ran out of things to do and they left the country in an absolute mess. Victoria, when the Liberal Party came to government there, was in an absolute state of chaos. People will remember that the Pyramid Building Society went down the drain. They sold off the State Bank. The joke around Australia, wherever you went as a Victorian, was: what is the capital of Victoria? The answer was: a dollar. That was the sort of thing people said.

In the papers today the people who comment on financial issues are saying that one of the outcomes of this election, if the Labor Party are elected with a slim majority, will be that capital will flow out of Victoria when businesses realise they are going to have to deal with the sort of Labor government they dealt with before. They will have to deal with people like Ben Hardman from Seymour, who is another union official. They will have to deal with Liz Beattie, who is a union official. They will have to deal with Ian Maxfield, who is a union official. They will have to deal with Ann Barker, who is a Labor staffer. They will have to deal with Jenny Lindell, who is a union staffer. They will have to deal with Geoff Howard, who is a Labor staffer. They will have to deal with Jacinta Allan in Bendigo East, who is a Labor staffer, and Joe Helper, who is a recent staffer. Joanne Duncan has actually done something—she has taught. So it goes on. What we will have is a replication of what we have in the Senate—people who are union hacks.

In Anne Henderson's book, Susan Ryan said, in relation to people in the Senate, that the reason they have people from the unions on the Senate side is that the unions do not want them. They get rid of them and put them into the Senate. That is exactly what Labor have done in Victoria, and the Victorian people will live to regret that they voted for a party which presented them with candidates who were nothing more than union hacks. The Victorian people were hoodwinked by the sorts of policies and unfunded promises that Labor made.

In the area of transport, they promised the people in Ballarat a fast train. The ALP cost of the fast train was $25 million. It must have been a choo-choo train—a kids toy train—that they were going to build, because its real cost is $60 million. There was a $35 million shortfall. The real cost of a fast train to Geelong was $30 million, but they said it was going to cost $20 million—a $10 million shortfall. A fast train to Bendigo was $50 million plus, but the ALP said it would cost $20 million. What is going to happen if the dice fall the way of the Labor Party in Victoria? The people in Bendigo, the people in Ballarat and the people in Geelong will live to rue the day they believed the promises of the Labor Party because they will go back to being the same old, tired Labor Party that makes promises. They say they are going to build a railway, but they cannot cost anything.

These people have never had to put their money where their mouth is. They have never had to run a business. They have never had to take risks. It will be demonstrated again in Victoria. It is not surprising to hear the opposition crowing from the rooftops when they have barely been able to whisper at the federal level. Where are the opposition policies? They are nowhere. Where are their successes at the federal level? They are nowhere. One might even be wondering if the federal Labor Party are actually still relevant at the policy level. Why is this? Because after 13 years of government they ran out of policies.

What will happen to the people of Victoria if the dice fall in that direction is that they will live to rue the day. They will have Victoria back as a basket case faster than you can say Jack Robinson. Capital will flow out and unemployment will be up. The Victorian people will live to rue the day they made that decision. Senator Conroy on the other side will be to blame for all of his number counting on that.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to see that Senator Alston has returned to the chamber, perhaps to enter the debate. Ask yourself what went wrong on the weekend, Senator Alston. When you are surrounded by people who make comments like `The Premier has worked very hard to help his state, and this is the thanks you get for it. Clearly he is the most experienced and successful Premier in Australia, perhaps in our history,' that could only come from Ron Walker, a man who cannot tell the difference between what is good for Victoria and good for Ron's pocket. That is what you have got happening here. No wonder they are out of touch.

speech.para: As I said, I am glad that Senator Alston is here, because I would like to know this, Senator. You recently referred an issue about false advertising to the ACCC. I would like to know if you received the following invitation, which was sent out a couple of weeks ago:

The Liberal Party of Australia Victorian Division requests the attendance of Senator Alston to celebrate the seventh anniversary of the first election of the Kennett government with the Premier of Victoria.

It is for Cabinet ministers and Liberal parliamentarians, at $1,000 a head. Talk about arrogance: the seventh anniversary of the election, with the Premier. Have you checked with Bracksey? We are not sure that he is going to be able to come. If Jeff is not the Premier, what I want to know is whether the people who have been suckered in by this advertising get their $1,000 back—because this will be false advertising in about a week.

We have seen in country Victoria some extraordinary results. We have seen Gisborne go with 10 per cent, Geelong, Ripon, Narracan, Seymour, Bendigo, Gippsland West, Mildura, Swan Hill, Gippsland East: they are the country and rural seats that are not coalition any more. We have seen the Labor Party with a swing of 7.5 per cent in country Victoria hold more regional and rural seats than the coalition. The coalition, which is represented in this place by senators on the other side of the chamber—roll over, Ron Boswell and Senator McGauran—has been just about wiped out. The Labor Party represents more seats in the Victorian parliament than your parties combined. That is the story from the weekend: four country independents, and the Nationals in free fall. But in particular we do owe a debt of thanks to Rob Knowles, because not only did Rob Knowles give us one seat but he cost you two, because we won his vacancy in Ballarat—two seats from Rob Knowles.

And what did we have? We had the gag. We have all heard and seen about the gag, but what actually happened? The Herald Sun is reporting that seven of the nine or 10 state coalition MPs they approached for comments lost their seats—seven of them that were gagged by their Premier lost their seats. Reflect on that. We can talk about Geoff Leigh. How do you gag Geoff Leigh? That is a big task. Even Senator Alston would admit that. Geoff Lee has said, `The gag thing obviously hurt us.' Obviously he has slipped the noose and slipped the gag, has Mr Lee—so you had better have a quiet word with him, Senator Alston.

We saw the Premier in a true blaze of glory last Wednesday on the Jon Faine show on 3LO. He was asked the question by Jon Faine and what happened? He turned around and said, `That is pathetic. I'm just going to sit here and drink my tea,' and he refused to answer the question. `I am going to sit here and drink my tea': that is treating the people of Victoria with contempt.

What goes around comes around. The people of Victoria have just made perfectly clear what they think of Jeff Kennett. Even Jeff Kennett had to admit yesterday, `A majority of people hate me.' Even in the papers today he was quoted as saying that there is an `unreal perception' out among country Victorians that he has ignored them. Well, an unreal perception? This bloke has not worked it out yet. He is on the front page of today's papers saying, `I may leave; I may quit.' I have got some big news for him: he is out of his job. He has actually lost and he has not noticed. He is still saying that it is up to him whether he leaves or not.

The big news is that country Victorians and all Victorians have spoken: 51 per cent of Victorians on the weekend voted for the Labor Party. Is it any wonder that Senator Alston did not want to face up to this in his question? Is it any wonder whatsoever? Is it any wonder, when you have got the arrogance to be announcing a seventh anniversary election with the Premier of Victoria to be held just after the election?

talk.start.para: —At $1,000 a head.

—At $1,000 a head. Is it any wonder that that sort of arrogance was rewarded on the weekend with the sorts of swings and the sort of massacre that took place in country Victoria? It will go on again. You are in trouble in Dunkley, you are in trouble in McEwen and you are in trouble in Ballarat. (Time expired)

—It is no surprise that the jackals were going to get up on Monday to dish out a bit of humility to the coalition. Of course there was an element of surprise in Saturday's Victorian election. It seemed to be a weekend of underdogs. Carlton won, the Melbourne Storm won, and Bracks did all right. But do not think that you have won government yet. I think you are jumping the gun. Just remember that you are over that side. If you think that in any way, shape or form this is going to reflect in a federal vote, you are absolutely kidding yourselves. Make very sure of that, on any analysis. In fact, I heard one commentator on the weekend say that this was a `protest vote gone too far'. That struck a chord with me, and we will see, if necessary, when the results come down in the Frankston East by-election. That will really tell the truth of things. It is still in the balance. Do not count your chickens. Talk about getting arrogant on Monday morning! You have learnt nothing. Where is the humility in you? Why aren't you humbled by the vote of the Victorian people, you bunch of arrogant—
—Order! Senator McGauran, it would be more appropriate if you were to address your remarks through the chair.

—All the points made by the previous government speaker, Senator Patterson, are correct. You will just revert back to kind in Victoria, for all the promises made by Bracks—who did a fair and good job; he is the only one at the front—because we know what is behind him. Senator Carr is behind him. If Mr Bracks gets in as Premier, are you going to return home? We know how you got up here: they shunted you up here, warehoused you here in 1992, when you had absolutely destroyed the Victorian Labor government. They shunted you up here to warehouse you, in the vain hope that they might get back in. Surprise, surprise! I suspect that you are going home if the Labor government gets back in, but you will go back as a staffer. They will wheel out Mother Russia again and give her some obscure job in the government. Senator Carr will go home to take up some major appointment, and it will be all back to the old days again.

speech.para: Nothing will have changed. It will be the same old faces, and the only person who will be different is Mr Bracks himself. He will be the only different face in the Labor Party. All the promises, all the spending, all the debt, all the old faces like Senator Carr's will return. That is something the Victorian people do not want. We know Senator Carr's record. We know why he got shunted up here, just for starters, because we only have to read John Cain's book John Cain's Years. Power, Parties and Politics. This book is absolutely riddled with references to Senator Carr. He has taken the full venom of John Cain regarding the years when he was a public servant, I believe. Were you a public servant? Good God. He was a public servant in the Cain government and the Kirner government!

Allow me to give you some choice quotes from the book about Senator Carr's efforts when he was working for the previous state government, because John Cain really cuts loose on him. There are so many of them I do not know where to begin and time will no doubt run out. But I want to put them on the record.

During December 1986 the heavy work on the Left members of Cabinet and Caucus continued. George Crawford and Kim Carr were responsible for `summoning' members to attend meetings of the Left executive.
That is cabinet members. The quote continues:

When ministers are `summoned' to meetings with party officers who can exercise considerable factional clout over their election or re-election to positions in Cabinet and/or their pre-selections, then you have got real problems in the government.
That is the sort of muscle work you were doing, Senator Carr: telling them how to spend the money and how much. It goes on and on. Time is going to run out but let me give you another choice quote:
As Kim Carr, a public servant in Joan Kirner's department, was leading the charge on this, I told Joan that she—

Where is the rest of this quote? I am missing a page. What a disappointment. I must speak to my secretary. I can tell you what John Cain probably told Joan Kirner: to get rid of him, get rid of Kim Carr. I have read the book that many times I can tell you what the quote is: `Get rid of Kim Carr. Shunt him off somewhere. Pension him off.' And what do you know: we have got him in the Senate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to pick up on a point that Senator McGauran made, because I think it takes us back to the question—
—Only one?

—Yes, only one, Senator Conroy. Senator McGauran asked: `Where is the humility?' This rabid raving we have heard on this issue really astounds me, so I have referred back to what the original question was, and I want to just paraphrase it again: what were the federal lessons from the state result, and what do certain Kennett policies on issues such as industrial relations, privatisation, regional issues, pet projects like car races and casinos and, finally, the government's arrogance mean for the federal government?

speech.para: What response did we get to that? We started out during question time with Senator Alston's response, which I would characterise as simply continuing the arrogance and the approach that Kennett has applied to Victoria. That is why I asked him whether he was going to submit his CV for more of the same. He stood here today in question time, and his collar got hotter and hotter and rose up his neck and he had to stick it back under. That was the response.

We now go to this session on taking note and we look at the responses we got from other senators. Senator Patterson went down the same path—that they are all a pack of union stooges et cetera. I want to correct the record on at least that one. I was not concentrating properly to hear the full diatribe from Senator Patterson, but it was the usual comments about the pack of union staffers involved in the Labor Party. She mentioned Ms Jenny Lindell, who I hope will succeed as the candidate for Carrum. We will probably know by the end of this week if that is definitely the case. Jenny Lindell, to my knowledge, never was a union staffer. She was an ALP staffer—she worked for me. Prior to that, she had many years of work in the community as a radiographer.

I am starting to get absolutely sick to death of these coalition references to anyone with an ounce of experience with the Labor Party or the union movement as being totally discredited. There are many people in the Labor Party and many people in the union movement who have very valuable and extensive community experience in professions like teaching and a variety of areas. Simply because someone has spent a few months perhaps in a Labor Party office or in a trade union does not write off the contribution they can make to this parliament. Again, the government continues to completely misrepresent that situation. I would challenge senators such as Senator Patterson to actually look at the full CVs of the people she refers to rather than just selectively pick out any tainted connection with a union or with the Labor Party—as she would characterise it.

Let me go back to Senator McGauran, who ponders over where the humility is. Can I suggest, Senator McGauran, that you should not blame your secretary for your own inadequacies. If you cannot find something in a speech, perhaps you could accept responsibility for it for yourself.

Again, what are the differences? The question was: what are the differences between the federal and the state level? I would argue that what we have had from the government today demonstrates that there is very little difference. You have not learnt from the level of arrogance that has been put into play in Victoria. Again, I want to highlight what Mr Bracks did on election night. That demonstrated humility. What Mr Bracks did was not claim some great personal victory; what he said was, `This is a victory for Victorians and this was a victory for democracy.' And that is what has come into play in Victoria. That is essentially what was also highlighted in today's editorial in the Financial Review. Yes, it is a big question about what is going to happen to Jeff now, because Jeff cannot lead in a democracy. He does not know how. All Jeff Kennett can do, all his style is suited to—

talk.start.para: —Senator Collins, would you please refer to the Premier of Victoria by his correct title.
—My apologies. All Mr Kennett can do is lead in an autocracy. That is all he knows. He will not be able to adapt to the new environment in Victoria.

speech.para: Terry McCrann in today's Herald Sun sees it as the demise of leadership. But many Victorians are pleased to see an environment—and in McCrann's schema there is an analogy with the Senate—that is based on consultation, cooperation and working with people and across a variety of groups. That is what Victoria can now experience rather than the autocracy that has been in place for many years. I am one of several who actually see that as an advance rather than a step back in leadership. (Time expired)

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We have had the usual superficial analysis of what went on in Victoria. The most important thing is what people had to say about the Labor Party, who seem to spend most of their time trying to paper over the cracks and hide the factionalism and tribal warfare that has been going on there for years, all the branch stacking that Mr Beazley does not have the stomach—and I use the term advisedly—to get in there and clean up.

speech.para: Essentially, they ran a pretty negative scare campaign and hoped that somehow they would improve their position sufficiently for the next three or four years when they could start to do some policy work. That is why respected commentators like Professor Brian Costar were saying on Saturday night that Labor did not deserve to win because they had not done any homework. That is the tragedy of it.

People in rural areas, who have a number of legitimate concerns, fell for Labor's three-card trick: do not worry about the problems, just vote for us and somehow we will get something going for you later on down the track. It will come very horribly unstuck and all the smart words after the event will not disguise the fact that no serious policy work had been done. That is the trap that federal Labor fall into as well. They thought they could get away with it for the first three years. Mr Beazley got a dream run, there was no real pressure on, everyone knuckled down because they thought, `We'll get back in 1998.' But, of course, they discovered they did not have any policies. We take the bush very seriously. We understand they have problems. They do not want promises; they want action. That is why we delivered them action.

talk.start.para: —Why did you gag the minister so they couldn't debate the policies?

—In stark contrast, people like Senator Conroy are getting up in caucus and saying, `We're going nowhere under Mr Beazley because he has no idea what motivates rural Australia.' That is very true. He does not. He dislikes going out there. As a last resort he is dragged out there by Cheryl Kernot and he scurries back home as quickly as he can.

speech.para: These are no substitute for policies. You have to spend a bit of time out there and really address the issues. Of course, if you do not have a trade union network out there, you have no motivation. I could understand why Senator Conroy prefers to just wander around the CBD, up to Lygon Street and out to a few of the usual suspects and make sure the numbers are okay, but that is nothing to do with policy formulation.

talk.start.para: —That's a lovely office in Castle Hill Place that you used to have.
—Do you mean in St Kilda Road?
—Yes.

—Yes, it was, until it was taken over by your mentor. That is very true. I must say that I do not aspire to return to it in the near future. There are serious issues in rural Victoria as there are in rural Australia. The Labor Party will always choose to ignore that there was a desperate need to get Victoria back on its feet. It was seriously depressed after the Cain-Kirner years.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I heard Senator Conroy say, `What goes around comes around,' which I presume means that Bracks would do it all again. I heard John Cain say it a couple of years ago. He was up at Bendigo or Ballarat celebrating a 100th anniversary and they asked him about those years and he said, `I'd do it all again.' It is a bit hard to educate people if they have that sort of mind-set. If you think that because you managed to pick up a few seats on the swings, many of which were ones that you never expected to—
—A few seats!
—You had to win 15. You still have not won them.
—On the record now, is Jeff going to be Premier in a month's time?

—I remember Mike Rann in South Australia got pretty close, didn't he? But getting close does not matter. And Neville Wran in fact won by only a couple of seats and powered away from it. Do not kid yourself. Even though there are commentators who are saying that Mr Beazley did very well at the last federal election, you know in your heart of hearts how very difficult it is. The next time around has nothing to do with the last time around. If you do not win, you start from scratch. You have to get down to the serious policy work. Enjoy it while you can. It is a nice little Indian summer that you are having. You picked up a lot of seats you did not expect to win.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Are you backing Mr Bracks, are you? Maybe there is a place for you back there. Maybe you could go back and give him some sensible advice. You would have a lot better prospects down there than I would have thought most of your colleagues would have up here. If it is a market opportunity, you should take advantage of it, Senator Conroy. There may well be undreamed of opportunities to actually get onto the front bench in Victoria that simply will not exist here in the foreseeable future.
