I do think it is difficult to determine at a time like this, when a draft motion has not been provided and when we are not quite clear what might be the decision of the House in relation to its own order of business, what it is appropriate for this chamber to do. I am making a bold assumption that the persuasive arguments of my colleagues in the House of Representatives in relation to the holding of a question time tomorrow will probably fall on deaf ears, will probably be unsuccessful, and that that is unlikely to take place. But I do make the important point that the government's motion in relation to the situation in East Timor should have been provided well before this time—that is, 9.25 p.m. on Monday of the first day of these important sittings of the parliament.

It is disappointing that we have not been provided with that motion. I do believe it is an important courtesy not just to the opposition but to all those in both chambers of the parliament who would like to make a contribution on an issue that has dominated public debate in our nation over the past few weeks. I am disappointed that the government has not been able to provide that motion. Of course, the opposition would much prefer to find itself in a position where it is in agreement with the government on a motion and there is some negotiating process between the government and opposition and other parties if they care to be involved about the appropriate wording of such a motion. It does appear that we have to deal with this issue before that matter is finally determined. I am afraid that I cannot apprise the Senate or any of my colleagues about the draft motion that is coming from the government.

In this circumstance, we find ourselves in a difficult position. It is an important principle that the motion be provided before we agree to such a debate. It is an important principle to hold a question time to hold the executive accountable for its role in relation to this important issue. I would have preferred the motion that we are debating now to have reflected those considerations. In the circumstances that we face where that is not possible, I think perhaps I am limited to making this short contribution on this matter to explain the approach that the opposition is taking, which is one that I think any fair-minded Australian or fair-minded member of the Australian parliament would accept as a very reasonable one in these circumstances.

So we await further developments in the House of Representatives. We would certainly encourage Mr Reith, as Leader of the House in the House of Representatives, to try to lift his game and ensure that the opposition is apprised of the government's motion on East Timor as soon as possible and to engage in the necessary discussions and negotiations in the way a matter as important as this ought to be progressed.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this motion. It would be helpful, however, if we could see, sometime this evening, the motion that is planned to be debated. I am sure most of us could write most of our speeches, having seen enough on the television screens about what is happening, but I say to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate that I think it would be conducive to a more fruitful debate if we could get a copy of the motion before we leave this evening.

—I am assured that the motion will be available. It probably is already available in that other place. Although I am sure Senator Faulkner's colleagues will earnestly, articulately and forcefully put the argument that there should be a question time tomorrow, the precedent to the best that I can judge from recent cases—I understand the debate on Somalia was one of those—is the debate on the Middle East conflict, the Gulf War. On 21 January 1991, the parliament was recalled to a special sitting. Question time was dispensed with then in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Senate made the decision to ensure that we mirrored what happened in the House of Representatives, which I would suggest is not always good practice. Their practices are often rules unto themselves.

speech.para: The Senate's procedures are often far better than those of the House of Representatives. We should not always seek to mirror them; we need to be a different place. But I do not think it is helpful that they debate East Timor over in that place and we engage in question time and other matters up here. It is appropriate that the statements or the motions be moved concurrently. That was very much the view put by Senator Robert Ray, the then Manager of Government Business in the Senate, on 21 January 1991, when he said:

There was no desire by the Government to hide from Question Time, but there was a desire to get on with this most important matter—as most people in the chamber would acknowledge—at the same time as the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —What did Hill say at the time?

—I think Senator Hill's words might have had an incredible resonance with what Senator Faulkner just said. I am sure Senator Hill put up a protest, as Her Majesty's opposition should always do. I genuinely appreciate the support from other senators and I undertake, on behalf of the government, to ensure that the draft motion is in the hands of all honourable senators in a very short time.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

These series of amendments and our amendment No. 8, which is to oppose section 1188D, all go to the same issue, which is the payment of parenting payments single to recipients of CDEP.

As I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage, this is one of the three major areas of concern that the opposition has with the bill. The minister and the government are seeking to make a number of changes to CDEP, most of which we support. They provide for allowing CDEP recipients to access some additional benefits that they have been traditionally denied, such as rental assistance, bereavement payment, telephone rental allowance and other ancillary benefits, and the opposition has no qualm with that. We think that is a positive and beneficial measure.

However, the opposition is concerned at what appears to be unfair treatment of those recipients of CDEP who also have access to parenting payment (single)—that is, single parents involved in CDEP work. We have ascertained, from looking at the legislation and from some research done for us done by the library, that it seems in excess of 4,000 sole parents may well be worse off as a result of the measure undertaken by the government. Those people would lose the entitlement to income, the sum of which would be over $100 a fortnight. These are often quite disadvantaged people such as Aboriginal people working in a CDEP project who are also single parents. By definition many of them suffer a range of disadvantages in terms of their access to the paid work force and to a range of other facilities in society because many of them live in remote communities.

While the other measures are beneficial, this is a very serious reduction in the amount of income paid to those 4,000 sole parents. At present, unlike other CDEP workers, sole parents have been able to access the sole parent pension—now the parenting payment (single)—in addition to a limited CDEP payment. CDEP income has been treated as ordinary income for any other sole parent pensioner—that is, it is an income free area—and any income in excess of that reduces parenting payment by 50 cents in the dollar. Sole parents working on CDEP projects have usually been paid CDEP income up to $124 a week, which is the income threshold for parenting payment and, in addition, they have received parenting payment.

While benefits payable to sole parent CDEP workers have been more generous than those available to other CDEP workers who are ineligible for social security benefits, their treatment is equivalent to that accorded to other sole parents who receive parenting payment (single). Again, CDEP income has been treated like any other sole parent pensioner's income. We believe this consistency is fair and the current entitlements should be retained. Sole parents experience particular difficulties in joining the work force, and their more generous treatment compared with other CDEP participants attempts to overcome this disadvantage. The measures proposed by the government in the bill would reduce parenting payment by one dollar for each dollar of CDEP income up to the amount of the parenting payment benefits. So there will be no income free area at all. Parenting payment would also be reduced by 50c for each dollar in excess of this amount.

We believe this would reduce the incentive to work and is not justified purely on the basis of arguing that this brings them down to a level occupied by other recipients. It provides a disincentive to work and it removes a small advantage that has been given to people who are amongst the most disadvantaged in the Australian community. To remove up to $100 a fortnight from these people, with the only justification seeming to be that it would bring them back to a level playing field, is not only insufficient but also highly unfair.

We think it is probably more a question of the government looking at a cost saving measure rather than at a measure based on any sort of merit. It would be very hard to argue that these people are receiving any great advantage in our society. They are in need of the sorts of support mechanisms that they are receiving currently, and it is easy to justify their continuing to receive those payments. We cannot at this stage see why, if it is not a cost cutting measure, the government would be looking to reduce their entitlements in this way.

We think that the current situation and regime provides a far fairer treatment for those people. We do not see why these 4,000 individuals who are struggling to work and to raise children on their own should be disadvantaged by this measure. I know the minister, in answering concern about the previous measure relating to the youth disability situation, said that such people may find it harder to get participation in CDEP projects because others would regard them as getting a double payment. That may or may not be true—I have no evidence for that, and none was advanced—but it seems to me that if there are some prejudices or difficulties we ought to work to overcome those prejudices and difficulties rather than seek to diminish the payments made to these people.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —The situation in East Timor over the past three weeks has been horrific. It is an absolute tragedy. I hope with all my heart, as do all Australians, that any further killing, violence, intimidation and forced removal of Timorese people will be averted or kept to the absolute minimum possible with the arrival of the United Nations peacekeeping force. People around the world have been shocked and appalled at this tragic turn of events.

speech.para: The people of Australia have been particularly affected for several reasons: the geographical proximity of the two regions, our past close historical ties with the Timorese and the large number of Timorese people in Australia.

I know this bond with the Timorese is a special one and will be a lasting one. The recent tragedy has led to many Australians working together with the East Timorese to alleviate their suffering as best they can. Nowhere is this more obvious than in Darwin.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the many people, agencies and organisations which have been involved in the relief effort to date and acknowledge the supreme efforts they have made. The brigades of volunteers and public servants deserve our thanks and praise.

The people of Darwin have opened their hearts to the East Timorese and have donated money, clothing, toys and time in a bid to help these people as best they can. Many Darwin people are acting as volunteers and assisting in any way they feel is right and useful.

On 10 September 1999, 478 people were evacuated from Dili. Of these, 344 were East Timorese. They arrived in Darwin by RAAF Hercules to a well-organised humanitarian relief effort. A further 1,500 East Timorese and almost 60 UN staff were evacuated by RAAF Hercules on 14 September 1999. The Northern Territory and federal governments had organised an East Timorese reception task force which originally used the Portuguese-Timorese Social Club as the reception centre for the refugees. Here they were processed efficiently and compassionately by Customs, Immigration and other officials in the first instance. The reception and processing of refugees was later moved to the Marrara Sports Stadium to accommodate the larger numbers involved. The East Timorese were given three-month safe haven visas similar to those granted to the refugees from Kosovo.

The reception task force, under the guidance of the Hon. Mike Reed MLA, the Northern Territory's Deputy Chief Minister, has done a superb job of making things as comfortable, simple and painless for the refugees as possible. The tent city erected by the Australian Army at the Kalymnian Social Club at Marrara is able to house 2,000 refugees in conditions that are the best possible for relief and temporary relief. The tent city is being run by the Northern Territory police and the officer in charge is Superintendent Mick Van Heythuysen. The tent city is a credit to the organisational skills of Superintendent Van Heythuysen and his officers, and also to its Timorese residents. A Timorese couple named their newborn infant after Superintendent Van Heythuysen and he will be a godfather to the baby. These actions show the depth of feeling that is being expressed on both sides in this crisis and is similar to the affection afforded the Australian Federal Police contingent in Timor for the recent poll.

Charity and aid organisations and many dedicated people from religious orders are playing a large part in the relief effort and, without their tremendous support, life for the refugees would be much more difficult. Anglicare has been collecting thousands of items of clothing for personal kits for the refugees. Their Darwin store has been open 24 hours a day as part of a drive to collect as many clothes as possible for the East Timorese. On a poignant note, it was requested that the clothes be of a small size and preferably of a dark colour due to the fact that the people were in mourning.

The Red Cross have also been doing a marvellous job. Their compound in Dili was stormed and they suffered strong intimidation from the militias, but this does not seem to have dented their resolve one iota. The Red Cross and their volunteers are working hard at the vital task of tracing families and attempting to provide information on the whereabouts of loved ones. They have also provided much needed assistance, with the local Darwin Timorese community, in helping refugees to fill out things such as immigration forms. The government aid organisation AusAID began food drops on 17 September with food and blankets dropped to refugees hiding in the hills south of Dili. These vital supplies may mean the difference between life and death for some people.

The aid workers who were in East Timor have had a particularly trying time. They have experienced some horrific episodes and must deal with those and also their feelings for those they were forced to leave behind. Their job is ongoing, in Darwin particularly, and it is an unfortunate reality that it will soon recommence in East Timor. They can take solace in the knowledge that they have already saved thousands of lives. Health Services Australia, working very closely with Northern Territory Health, was able to mobilise seven medical staff within 24 hours and by today had screened around 1,100 refugees, with about 500 to go. Doctors worked throughout the weekend to ensure refugees were screened in the most humane and sensitive manner, and the staff of Health Services Australia, the Royal Darwin Hospital and Territory Health Services must be congratulated. Reports indicate that people being seen are malnourished and psychologically traumatised. Those people with health problems have been hospitalised in the Northern Territory.

Hotels and motels around Darwin were absolutely full as those East Timorese who had passed through immigration and health checks were moved out of the tent city into more appropriate accommodation on 12 and 13 September. On 18 September, 292 refugees were flown to Melbourne to stay at Puckapunyal army base ahead of a further 300. Several hundred Timorese community members from Melbourne were on hand to greet them, continuing the strong support their compatriots in Darwin have shown. I am sure the refugees who will be accommodated at Puckapunyal in Victoria, Leeuwin in Western Australia and East Hills in New South Wales will be as well looked after as they were in Darwin.

The troops from Townsville, and particularly my constituents from the Northern Territory based in Darwin, Palmerston and Katherine who are forming such a vital part of the UN peacekeeping force, deserve a strong message of thanks and good wishes. I, along with all Territorians and the rest of Australia, wish them godspeed and a safe campaign. The hopes and wishes of all Territorians go with them, particularly the 2,000 troops who left today from Darwin. The RAAF has played a strong role in the lead-up to the peacekeeping force leaving today. The Hercules crews who flew the evacuation flights and who flew supplies to the besieged UNAMET compound showed determination and courage in conditions that were extremely adverse.

The head of the United Nations mission on East Timor, Mr Ian Martin, who flew out of Dili only on Tuesday, 14 September with the 1,500 refugees from the UN compound, showed extreme courage and wise judgment in circumstances few of us can imagine. I would also like to pay tribute to the journalists who have been covering the crisis from Timor and Darwin. The coverage has, in the large majority, been responsible and sensitive, with the journalists from international and local media following and understanding the need for rules that have been set.

Finally, I think it is important to acknowledge and applaud the strength and the courage that the East Timorese refugees themselves have shown in such trying circumstances. They are exceptional people, and the recognition they gave to the Prime Minister today at the tent city shows the feelings they have for all Australians. I pray for peace in their troubled country.

talk.start.para: —At the end of last week I had the pleasure of being the guest of Scott Anderson and his partner Anna on a Flinders Island property. Together with Scott and Anna, I was the guest of Scott's parents, David and Kath Anderson. The property, which is a consolidation of three former soldier settlement blocks, is run by Scott, his father David and his mother Kath. It produces wool, lamb and beef and is trialling cauliflower seed production. The opportunity to visit the Andersons was presented by the rural visit component of the leadership training program, a program of the Tasmanian Rural Industry Training Board and the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association.

speech.para: It gave me the opportunity not only to get a first-hand view of the operation with a bit of hands-on work but to spend time talking to Scott, Anna, David and Kath about the issues that impact on them. It was also an opportunity to get their views not only on the issues that they face and those with which the government might assist them in the economic endeavours but also on the broader issues that impact on rural communities, such as Flinders Island.

I must say that the Anderson's farming operation is an impressive one. Their approach to farming is very much a scientific one. For example, I observed that stock growth is closely monitored to ensure that cattle and sheep are turned off to market when they reach optimum weight. Scott and David Anderson have also worked hard to increase the quality of their cattle herd by a careful mixing of on-farm bloodlines with those of carefully selected bulls from other properties. The increasing role of science illustrated by the Anderson's operation as well as the consolidation of the properties—as I said earlier, in the Anderson's case three farms into one—is essential if rural Australia is not only to recover from the decline it has experienced in recent years but to grow. I would like to put on the record my appropriation to Scott, Anna, David and Kath for an opportunity to spend some time with them and gain a better understanding of the issues in regional Australia.
Another communication occurred on the weekend. The residents of regional Victoria also had an opportunity to communicate with politicians at the end of last week through the ballot box.

talk.start.para: —Oh no, you were going so well.
—I am glad that Senator McGauran is here. Isn't it wonderful, Senator McGauran, that somebody gets out of the big cities into the country?
—Is that why you left Sydney?

—That is a very good comment, Senator Macdonald. You have been saying for some time that all of the occupants of this side of the chamber are from the cities; now you have conceded that in fact I left Sydney to go to a rural and regional area. You have defeated your own arguments with that pathetic interjection.

speech.para: Throughout the Victorian election campaign residents of regional Victoria heard the Premier, Mr Kennett, talking about how well things were going in that state. He was happy to tell anyone that Victoria was in great shape. He claimed that his government had delivered substantial economic growth, and he rattled off statistics to back up his claim. He said he had created a record number of jobs. He said investment in Victoria was booming. He was keen to tell people living in regional Victoria that that state now enjoys a AAA credit rating. But we now know that, as people started thinking about how they were going to vote last Saturday, they were not listening to Mr Kennett; they were asking themselves whether they were getting their fair share of the good times and successes that Mr Kennett kept talking about.

talk.start.para: —Not just Ron Walker.
—Senator Conroy, it is disorderly to interject out of your place.

—They were asking whether they were getting their fair share of Mr Kennett's spending on health, on education, on housing and on government services. The massive vote against Mr Kennett in the bush suggests that the general view was that they received very little. In their eyes, to have any chance of benefiting from the policies of the Kennett government you obviously needed to be well off and living in the city. If you lived in the bush, of course, you received very little or nothing. If Mr Kennett was spending a fair share of health, education, training, job creation and government services funding in regional Victoria, then no-one noticed.

speech.para: What did Minister Alston say today? He said that the abysmal vote that the coalition—and, particularly, the National Party—received in Victoria on the weekend was the result of `declining standards of living in the bush' in rural and regional Victoria. What an admission—the great achievements of the Kennett government were leading only to declining living standards in the bush!

Of course, the same charge can be levelled at the Howard government. Regional Australia has gone backwards since this government was first elected. Unemployment is much greater in regional areas than in the cities. The youth unemployment rate is significantly higher in regional Australia. Tragically, youth suicide is also higher and school retention rates much lower. Medical services in the bush are barely adequate, if that.

These statistics are the starting point for young people who might not want to migrate to the major cities. They are the starting point if you are unemployed and looking for a job or if you are trying to get a better one. They are the starting point if you or a member of your family becomes ill and needs medical attention.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, keeps saying that regional Australia does not want government handouts. He says that regional Australia needs to stand on its own. Frankly, he does not understand what this is all about. Public expenditure on essential services is not about charity. It is not about living off the public purse. If regional communities were given their fair share of the public dollar, not only would we have access to the same level of services as people living in Melbourne or Sydney but the government would be investing in the future of the bush.

Public expenditure on key services in regional Australia is the only way it can build a future. Spending on education now means a more skilled work force in the future. Spending on health care now means a healthier, more productive work force. Increased spending by the government in regional areas is also an important investment in the national economy. Regional economies like Flinders Island and farmers like the Anderson family make an important contribution to my state and to the national economy.

When Mr Kennett claimed credit for a four per cent growth in GDP, he was claiming credit for the efforts of wool producers, meat workers, timber workers, the fishing industry, the horticulturalists, the gas industry and the tourism industry, all of which make up regional economies. Rural communities throughout Australia produce the national wealth. In many respects the cities spend it. Mr Kennett, Mr Howard and Mr Costello all claim credit for it.

With the right policies for the key industries such as on Flinders Island and in Gippsland in Victoria, and with the right level of public services, regional Australia can make an even greater contribution to national wealth. In doing so, we can ensure that the people who live outside the major cities have a brighter and more prosperous future.

talk.start.para: —My main contribution tonight will be in the area of social security and welfare policy—and we have just spent some time in this chamber debating legislation on this subject. Before I get on to that I would like to make a couple of other comments following on from what Senator O'Brien said about the Victorian election. I would like to offer my congratulations not just to all the people who participated in the election, including the electorates themselves, but to the Democrat candidates who participated in it. It is not perhaps surprising that their achievements have been somewhat overshadowed by the unexpected outcome of the election in terms of the result in the lower house there and the potential change of government—or certainly change in the style of government.

speech.para: Nonetheless, it is worth highlighting the significant result that many of the Democrat candidates achieved. It certainly highlighted that any suggestion of an electoral backlash was unfounded in relation to some of the actions of the Democrats at a federal level in this chamber in recent times. Despite spending far less than we did last time at a state level in Victoria, our vote significantly increased in a majority of seats. Indeed, in the upper house seat of Higginbotham it was around 44 per cent on recent counts.

I especially congratulate Craig Tucker for the work he did there and also all of the other candidates who battled very hard in the absence of any mainstream media coverage. All the focus was on the larger parties and perhaps the one large premier, who had a fixation of making sure the election was focused on him. Obviously it focused a bit too much on him and, as it turned out, that was not actually a good idea. Democrat candidates did work hard at the local level and achieved an increase in the vote. The preferences of Democrat voters were clearly crucial in a number of lower house seats and this could lead to a change in government. I think that should be recognised.

It should also be recognised that if we had a proportional representation system in the upper house in Victoria, such as we do in virtually every other upper house in Australia, then we would clearly have Democrats represented in the Victorian upper house. While Mr Kennett would never admit it, it may well have been to his advantage to have had a bit of a tempering influence in parliament on some of his more outrageous attributes in recent years. He may actually still have found himself the undisputed premier of that state if he had had a bit of discipline forced on him by an upper house in the same way that the discipline of checks and balances provided by this chamber has, I would argue, been a benefit rather than a hindrance to the popularity and to the effectiveness of both this government and previous governments.

In a more sombre vein, I would also like to mention a couple of other Democrats—Democrat stalwarts who, sadly, passed away. I would like to pay a brief tribute to them this evening. Jim Coates, who people here in the ACT would be well aware of, was a candidate for us in the last territory elections here. Certainly he was far more than that: he was a very helpful person all round to the party and a long-term member. He was very opinionated, as Canberra residents would be aware of from his very frequent contributions to letters to the editor. He was also a very strong advocate of social justice and human rights, particularly in some of the areas I am involved in on behalf of the party, such as refugees and the rights of migrants. From the reportedly large turnout at his funeral, he was a person who will be sadly missed, particularly within the Democrats.

I would also like to pay tribute to a Queensland member, Glenn Polson, who died just yesterday. He was a candidate for us in the seat of Groom, based around Toowoomba, in the last federal election. Again, he was someone who provided a lot of support for the party and helped to keep it going in an area in which it is a little bit more difficult for people to contribute because of the smaller number of members outside the capital cities. He was supportive of the party and provided a lot of assistance without ever seeking any personal gain. I very much appreciate his contribution and pay tribute to it here this evening.

Given that my throat seems to be collapsing, I might pass up on what was going to be a fabulous speech in relation to social security policy. However, I will briefly touch on it. This area has always been important. There has been a lot of focus in the media in recent years, and another wave of it in more recent times, about the role and future of welfare policy. That is a concern that the Democrats share.

As with many issues in this fast changing society, economy and community, we cannot stand still in any area; and welfare policy and social security and income support policy is just another one of those areas. But, when we do that, it is very important that we ensure that, whilst we may need to change our focus about how best to deliver that policy, we do not change the fundamental underpinnings of the purpose of that policy, which is to ensure that the less well-off are provided with support in times of need and that assistance is provided to them across a range of different measures and that the budgetary or economic focus does not get primacy.

As I said in this chamber an hour or so ago in relation to social security legislation, whilst there can be some good rhetoric about simplification or rationalisation of our income support system or about ensuring that people get provided with particular incentives or assistance in different ways other than money—and that is all true—oftentimes those sorts of arguments can be just a cover for budgetary savings; and that tends to be the bottom line that drives a lot of policy. The main job of many people in the political sphere seems not to be coming up with new ideas about how to improve assistance to people in need but coming up with new rhetoric, new spin and new glib-sounding phrases to cover up the fact that it is just another attempt to slice some money out of the welfare budget.

Certainly, from the Democrats' point of view, whilst we definitely concur that there is a lot more to welfare, income support and social security than just providing money, I would like to see anybody try to get by without money, as well: it is still a fundamental component of providing assistance. Certainly, on behalf of the Democrats, we will be keeping a close watch on the reality and on any actual outcome of the proposed policy changes from all political parties in this area of policy debate.

talk.start.para: —I add my words of congratulations to the Democrats in Victoria for a very successful campaign on Saturday and in the weeks leading up to the election. We did particularly well in many seats, particularly with Craig Tucker in Higinbotham, with 44 per cent of the vote. The number of very young candidates who were standing for the Democrats is a good sign for the party for the future. I also congratulate the ALP on a good campaign.

speech.para: I rise primarily tonight to talk about the revolution which has been started in Victoria's education system—one of the reasons that the Kennett government fared so badly on Saturday. It could have profound ramifications for the rest of Australia too, and anyone concerned about the future of public education in this country should be watching the Victorian experiment.

Back in June, the tensions within two Melbourne secondary schools erupted outside the school gates. Sandringham and Blackburn secondary colleges had become self-governing schools, and parents and teachers at both schools united to protest at the lack of consultation by principals in the decision to become self-governing. They formed pickets at the gates and they stopped work.

The Victorian government hailed self-governance as bringing flexibility, less red tape, and prosperity, yet only 51 schools have so far signed up—just three per cent of all schools in Victoria. The Victorian government went on the record some time ago to say that it expected to have 200 schools by now—and that is not exactly, to employ Mr Costello's parlance, a beautiful set of figures. In fact, fortunately it is a dismal set of figures.

The policy has been such a flop that the state government hired a consultant to find out why schools were thumbing their noses at self-governance, and the de Bono Institute was brought in to pitch to small schools the benefits of self-governance. Edward de Bono is no stranger to Victorian politics. This master of lateral thinking intervened a few years ago in the tramways dispute on a visit to Melbourne. He sided with the Kennett government in sacking tram conductors—yet another reason why the election went so badly for the coalition.

I know of schools that were able to generate only a few hundred dollars last year in fundraising, and harried principals said it was extremely difficult to get parents involved in school life in some schools. In some areas, few parents spoke English and many were focusing all their energies on providing for their children, on minimal or no wages. What these schools need, in my view, is a firmer commitment from government, not a lesser commitment. Autonomy rings hollow when it is granted in a climate of chronic underresourcing.

We know that Victoria has dropped its spending per capita on education lower than that of any other state or territory. I sincerely hope that if Labor—or even a humiliated Liberal government—forms government in Victoria it will turn those figures around. We have recently seen a new class of 12 specialist self-governing schools created in Victoria, and they will have access to private funding raised by the Education Trust, recently established by the state government. Of course, no other public schools will have access to this money, no matter how much they need it. The Education Trust threatens the operations of the Education Foundation, a non-profit, independent organisation that devotes itself to raising money for public schools.

Over the last 10 years, the foundation has raised more than $1 million. This money has funded 300 projects directly involving 200 schools. Rather than offer grants to a select few, the foundation has supported public schools across the socioeconomic spectrum. Those projects have included refugee work experience in Brunswick, a science club in Balwyn, a Women in the Local Workforce project at Drouin, a girls construction project in Melbourne's south-east, a gifted students extension project at Noble Park, self-defence for disabled students at Northcote, a Koori garden at Timboon, a Girls in Electronics project at Preston, and participation in the Victorian Model Solar Car Challenge at an inner Melbourne school. Donors to the Education Foundation have included BP, Rio Tinto, Australia Post and Telstra. It is not difficult to envisage that any new trust bearing the state government's imprimatur would divert corporate funds away from the Education Foundation, and this would be indeed lamentable.

Commercial fundraising for public schools is notoriously difficult, and we need a body that is able to help public schools on the basis of need. We should note too that, of the 12 schools that will be beneficiaries of the new Education Trust, not one is in Melbourne's west, the most disadvantaged region in Melbourne in terms of education outcomes. I hear that none of the principals who have gone down the self-governing route have done it on an educational basis. In fact, I doubt that any work has been done to look at educational outcomes. The deciding factor has been competition with the public school further down the road.

Many schools that have considered going down the self-governing route have backed out because the sums just do not add up. Self-governing schools forfeit many services normally available to schools on a regional basis through the department. Of the $125 per capita grant to self-governing schools, $105 is meant to pay for the following services that used to be provided by the department: support for discipline cases and professional development activities; employee assessment; gifted students program; curriculum support, including materials and training for gifted education programs; programs delivered via CD-ROM, satellite and video for languages other than English; school global budget advice and redeployment assistance; assistance with school council elections; student welfare; and student services, including speech pathology, visiting teachers, social workers and curriculum coordinators. And the list goes on. In addition to that $125, self-governing schools get a one-off payment of $30,000. Clearly, this deal does not go anywhere near making up for the lack of departmental support.

There is a staff allocation of $45,000 per teacher. That means that any self-governing school with experienced teachers will not have enough money to pay for them, because this amount represents an average teachers salary. It does not reflect the number of experienced teachers within a school who could expect to command more. This arrangement favours schools that hire large numbers of contract teachers. It inevitably means reduced pay and conditions. I am sure the Senate will agree that this is not a promising development, given the report of the Senate inquiry into the status of teachers, A class act, which identified pay as a significant problem in attracting and keeping teachers.

One observer of the international trend towards self-governing schools noted Oscar Wilde's remark that socialism would never work because it would take up too many evenings. A similar fate, I might suggest, could befall self-governing schools.

In the US, private schools enrol only 20 per cent of students. Their version of self-governing schools is charter schools, which make up less than one per cent of all schools. The grant-maintained schools ushered in by Thatcher constitute only four per cent of schools in the UK. In the United States the experience is that students with disabilities have been screened out, as have students from undesirable ethnic backgrounds, via conditions such as zero tolerance and parental involvement contracts. Many states have allowed charter schools to circumvent local regulations and collective bargaining agreements. Schools have even used uncertified teachers. They are also an untested experiment. Research in 1998 showed that three-quarters of US charter schools were less than two years old. Evaluation is a long way off. At this stage of the proceedings, the push for charter schools is based on ideology rather than analysis. Phrases such as `Our public schools are failing' readily fall from proponents' mouths.

I think Australia must ask itself if it really wants to emulate American charter schools that are unashamedly dog eat dog in their recruiting—schools with names like ABC, which stands for `All the Best Children'. The growth of American charter schools has been largely unregulated. That sounds somewhat familiar because, in Australia, since the Howard government abolished the new schools policy, private schools here have been allowed to start up with as few as 20 students and receive federal funding to pay for most of their costs. The municipality of Maribyrnong, in Melbourne's west, is without public schools—Mr Kennett closed them down shortly after he came to power. Yet the same municipality now has a number of new private schools. (Time expired)

The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Disability Discrimination Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 1):
(1) Who, if anyone, was consulted in the drafting of these regulations.

(2) Was the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the acting Disability Discrimination Commissioner consulted or informed about the drafting of the regulations exempting state laws from the Disability Discrimination Act.
(3) In the future, before any further regulations are made exempting the Disability Discrimination Act, will the Attorney-General consult with:
(a) the Minister for Family and Community Services;
(b) the Disability Discrimination Commissioner (or acting Commissioner); and

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) In October 1993 the then Attorney-General wrote to the State and Territory Attorneys-General, and again in March 1995 and December 1995, concerning the need to review legislation and to either remove such inconsistencies as exist, or where necessary, seek prescription of laws pursuant to section 47(2) of the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA). Requests for prescription were received from several States and Territories. The review of the requests for prescription from New South Wales (NSW) and South Australia resulted in the making of the Disability Discrimination Amendment Regulations 1999.

It is relevant to note section 132(2) of the DDA which provides that, before making any regulations for the purposes of section 47 of the DDA, the Governor-General is to take into consideration any comments made to the Minister by a Minister of a State or Territory who is responsible for matters relating to disability discrimination. This statutory requirement was complied with in the making of these regulations.

(2) While neither the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) nor the Disability Discrimination Commissioner were formally consulted in relation to the individual requests for prescription from NSW or South Australia, officers of the Attorney-General's Department discussed the prescription process with officers of the HREOC.

(3) The DDA indicates that responsibility for consultation with relevant stakeholders lies with the individual State or Territory which is seeking to have its legislation prescribed. Accordingly, the Attorney-General will seek formal assurances from the relevant State or Territory Minister that any necessary consultation with all stakeholders has taken place before any further prescription is undertaken.
In addition the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Office of Disability in the Department of Family and Community Services will be consulted on any future proposed prescriptions.

subdebateinfo.title: Community Development Employment Project Participants: Pay Rates
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1250)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 13 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What is the hourly rate paid to Community Development Employment Project participants.
(2) Is the same hourly rate paid to CDEP participants throughout Australia.
(4) What award, if any, covers CDEP participants.
(5) Do organisations which have CDEP participants have employer/employee responsibilities; if so, what are they.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There is no set single hourly rate paid to Community Development Employment Project (CDEP) participants. Wages funding is provided to CDEP organisations on the basis of the following weekly per participant amounts:
. remote $185.73; and
. non-remote $167.27.
The actual rates paid to CDEP participants vary within and between CDEP organisations and are dependent on a range of factors including:
. the type of work being performed;
. the number of hours worked; and
. the presence or otherwise of a an award rate.

ATSIC has provided advice to CDEP organisations informing them of the National Minimum Safety Net Wage Decision and indicating that an hourly rate derived from this weekly rate should form the basis of a minimum hourly rate for all CDEP participants.
(2) No, as indicated in the previous answer, rates paid to CDEP participants vary across Australia.
(3) In some instances, the rates paid to CDEP participants are based on award rates applicable to the type of work being carried out by the participant.

(4) Many participants in CDEP organisations are to varying extents, covered by some form of awards, most notably State Common rule awards that cover those participants performing work under the coverage of these awards. In terms of specific awards that were developed and implemented to cover CDEP organisations and their participants ATSIC is only aware of the following two awards:
. a NSW State Award covering the Nungera CDEP at Maclean NSW; and
. a Federal Award covering the Yalata CDEP organisation in South Australia.

(5) The report of the Independent Review of the Community Development Employment Project (CDEP) Scheme (Spicer Report) published in December 1997 reaffirmed that an employer and employee relationship exists between CDEP participants and CDEP organisations. In this context the respective responsibilities are the same as for other community based organisations performing similar roles. ATSIC in its funding guidelines has always directed organisations, including CDEPs, that they are to follow all legal requirements in respect of their responsibilities as employers. To provide additional impetus and assist organisations in clarifying and meeting their responsibilities, ATSIC is in the process of implementing a specific recommendation from the Spicer Report to encourage all CDEP organisations to adopt formal employee regulation of their participants.
